awd_titl_txt: Complexity-building Approaches in Photoassisted Synthesis of Heterocycles
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Andrei Kutateladze, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Denver. The research is focused on developing new methods for synthesis of complex organic molecules containing multiple ring substructures. This will be done using photons of light as an environmentally abundant and safe reagent and the approach achieves structural complexity with a minimal number of experimental steps. Besides the fundamental importance of learning about interactions of light and matter in the context of synthetic chemistry, the targeted complex polyheterocycles (i.e. molecules which contain nitrogen, sulfur, or oxygen atoms as a part of a ring) are intentionally designed to resemble alkaloids (a class of naturally occurring organic bases) and other biologically active natural products that may potentially possess useful therapeutic properties. Importantly, this award supports research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from historically underrepresented groups in science, provided them with useful skill sets in modern organic chemistry and photochemistry; excellent preparation for career paths in either academia or industry.

This research expands the toolbox for excited state intramolecular proton transfer (ESIPT)-based synthetic photochemistry with several new photo-assisted synthetic reaction cascades.  The photo-induced reaction cascades allow the experimentalist to achieve large step-normalized complexity increases and rapidly assemble novel fused polyheterocyclic molecular architectures. Additional growth of complexity is realized through post-photochemical transformations, such as multi-step carbocationic cascades and rearrangements. Investigations of reaction mechanisms and stereochemistry of these ESIPT-triggered cascades help achieve control of stereochemical and regiochemical outcomes.  This experimental work is augmented by computation, especially to facilitate solution structure elucidation of the complex polyheterocyclic products by NMR. The new integrated DU8+ method for fast and accurate calculation of NMR parameters includes PCM models and solvent-specific parameterization schemes.  This computational tool is are critical for success of this project, but also has broader implications for structure elucidation of complex synthetic and natural product target molecules. Additionally, this research provides hands-on laboratory training for graduate and undergraduate students, and research associates, especially those from historically underrepresented groups in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project Professor Andrei Kutateladze of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at University of Denver developed new methods for the synthesis of complex organic heterocycles.  These are substances which contain nitrogen in a ring.  They are important and ubiquitous in many areas of chemical sciences, from materials science to medicinal chemistry. In our work, new synthetic routes to these complex molecules are developed, which are primarily based on novel elaborate cycloaddition reactions initiated by ultraviolet light. Complex polyheterocyclic molecular architectures are accessed and alkaloid mimics are synthesized, which possess potential therapeutic properties. The crowning achievement of this work is the development of several cascade photoreactions to form multiple chemical bonds in one experimentally simple step.  This allows for the use of simple renewable chemical feedstock as a starting point for synthesis of very complex molecules possessing useful properties.  It was particularly important that a number of such photochemical cascades included dearomative cycloadditions in benzenoid aromatic compounds, which are ubiquitous and broadly available.  These new impactful synthetic methods are poised to improve the pipelines for drug design and discovery.  While biological applications of the synthesized polyheterocycles were outside of the scope of this project, we forwarded most of them to be tested at the National Cancer Institute (NCI-60).

As complexity of these synthesized molecules increases (as quantified with computer-generated molecular complexity scores such as the Boettcher index), it becomes increasingly more challenging to determine their structure. To that end, fundamentally important efforts were directed at facilitating solution structure elucidation of these polyheterocycles and other complex organic molecules, including important classes of natural products found in nature.  This is achieved by further development of the DU8 suites of theoretical/computational methods created in the Kutateladze lab to predict nuclear magnetic resonance properties of complex molecules to accurately identify their molecular structure.   In this funding cycle, the DU8+ method was taken to the next level by augmenting the Density Functional Theory of calculations with a Machine Learning module.  This dramatically improved the accuracy of predictions, while not affecting the time of computations, which was held at 30-50min per structure of an average sesquiterpene or diterpene.  This is a very challenging task for large organic molecules, but it is critically important to accurately determine molecular structures because useful properties of such molecules, especially potential therapeutics or modern materials, depend on molecular structure.  The new method, DU8ML, developed during this funding cycle allows for accurate calculations of nuclear magnetic resonance spectra obtained in deuterated chloroform, facilitating molecular structure elucidation.

One of the most important broader impacts of this grant is the training of the next generation of practitioners in the field of organic chemistry. This NSF support allowed for the training of four graduate students, three research associates (partially supported on this grant) and a number of undergraduate students, especially women and those from historically underrepresented groups in science.  The multifaceted nature of this project allowed for training opportunities on a broad range of research skills.   All participants were exposed to a classical synthetic chemistry research.  In addition, all of them received training in photochemical and photophysical techniques: running photochemical reactions in batch and flow modes; determining relative quantum yields by irradiating samples in carousel photoreactors, determining isotope effects on photochemical quantum yields, elucidating complex molecular structures with sophisticated NMR experiments and theoretical/computational analysis.

Another important area of broader impacts emerging from this grant is in the increased availability of complex polyheterocyclic molecular architectures for other disciplines and scientific fields, from materials science to drug design and discovery. 

The search for novel complexity-building reactions assisted by light continues.  This is an ongoing program.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Andrei G Kutateladze
